titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Benjamin Aaron Papers LSC.0413
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by UCLA Library Special Collections staff, revisions by Kelly Besser with assistance from Megan Hahn Fraser in consultation with University Archivist Charlotte Brown, 2013; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√©.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-11-30 11:50:05 -0800.

did.unittitle: Benjamin Aaron papers
did.abstract: UCLA Professor of Law Emeritus Benjamin Aaron's principal field of study was labor law and industrial relations with a special emphasis on comparative labor law. Materials include arbitration case files, conference files, documents pertaining to Aaron's involvement in the National Academy of Arbitrators, the Industrial Relations Research Association, and the International Society of Labor Law and Social Security, correspondence, UAW Public Review Board documents, publications authored by and collected by Aaron, drafts of Aaron's memoirs, and files concerning the UCLA Ad Hoc Committee chaired by Aaron to examine three allegations against Acting Assistant Professor of Philosophy, Angela Y. Davis.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Portions of this collection are restricted. Consult finding aid for additional information.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS DIGITAL MATERIALS: This collection contains both processed and unprocessed digital materials. Digital materials are not currently available for access, unless otherwise noted in a Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note at the series and file levels. All requests to access processed digital materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Benjamin Aaron papers (Collection 413). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Benjamin Aaron donated to UCLA University Archives, November, 1994. University Archivist Charlotte Brown received additions in November, 2007.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by UCLA Library Special Collections staff, revisions by Kelly Besser with assistance from Megan Hahn Fraser in consultation with University Archivist Charlotte Brown, 2013.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Benjamin Aaron was born on September 2, 1915 in Chicago, Illinois. He graduated from the University of Michigan in 1937, and received his law degree from Harvard in 1940. In 1946 Aaron joined UCLA's Institute of Industrial Relations, and became its director in 1960. That same year, he joined the faculty of the UCLA School of Law. Aaron was a distinguished scholar of labor law and published widely in the field. He served on many panels, boards, and commissions as an appointee of Presidents Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, and George H.W. Bush, such as The National Commission on Technology, Automation, and Economic Progress. During his career he served as president of National Academy of Arbitrators, the Industrial Relations Research Association, and the International Society of Labor Law and Social Security. He became Professor of Law Emeritus in 1986. Aaron died August 25, 2007 in Los Angeles, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection contains documents pertaining to the career of Benjamin Aaron, a scholar of labor law and law school professor at UCLA. Materials include arbitration case files, conference files, documents pertaining to Aaron's involvement in the National Academy of Arbitrators, the Industrial Relations Research Association, and the International Society of Labor Law and Social Security, correspondence, UAW Public Review Board documents, publications (both authored by and collected by Aaron), drafts of Aaron's memoirs, and files concerning the UCLA Ad Hoc Committee chaired by Aaron to examine three allegations against Acting Assistant Professor of Philosophy, Angela Y. Davis.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection maintains the creator's original order and file names.

scopecontent.head: General note
scopecontent.p: Ad Hoc Committee Report to Chancellor Charles E. Young concerning its examination of three allegations against Acting Assistant Professor of Philosophy, Angela Y. Davis. This report is signed by Chairman Benjamin Aaron and the following professors: Walter R. Goldschmidt, Wendell P. Jones, Ada B. Nisbet, Charles R. Nixon, Lynn White and Robert M. Yost. Materials also include the American Association of University Professors (AAUP) Statement on Professional Ethics and Statement on Academic Freedom.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - Public Speeches

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Materials include transcripts of Davis' speeches at Campbell Hall, Pauley Pavillion, Berkeley's Lower Plaza and the Thirteenth Annual People's World Banquet.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - Lecture Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Copies of six lectures from Fall Quarter.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - Department of Philosophy Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Correspondence to Department of Philosophy Chairman Donald Kalish and Philosophy Professor David Kaplan concerning Davis' qualifications as an educator.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - AAUP Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Copies of AAUP Bulletins concerning academic freedom and tenure.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - Course Evaluation Sheets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Copies of course evaluations for Davis' Philosophy 99, Philosophy 107 and Philosophy 180.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - Correspondence

scopecontent.head: General note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning Davis' dismissal, Communist Party membership and the Angela Davis Fund.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - Academic Senate

scopecontent.head: General note
scopecontent.p: Materials include University of California, Los Angeles Division of the Academic Senate Resolutions and Minutes concerning the Angela Davis Case, the UCLA Department of Philosophy's Statement of Facts Concerning the Appointment and Threatened Dismissal of Professor Angela Davis, press releases issued by Angela Y. Davis and Associate Professor of Philosophy, David Kaplan, a leaflet from the Committee for an Orderly University, a statement from the UCLA Committee of Concerned Faculty which includes a calendar of events in the case and the Angela Davis Defense Committee's Policy Statement concerning the Regents' dismissal of Davis.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - Ad Hoc Committee

scopecontent.head: General note
scopecontent.p: Materials include correspondence from Chairman Aaron to members of the Ad-Hoc Committee, a statement to the Regents regarding the reappointment of Davis, a letter from Chancellor Charles Young to the Ad-Hoc Committee and clippings.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - AAUP Draft Report

scopecontent.head: General note
scopecontent.p: A copy of the AAUP Draft Report concerning the Davis case and correspondence concerning revisions.

did.unittitle: Angela Davis - Correspondence and Minutes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, Committee on Academic Freedom Minutes and Committee on Educational Policy Minutes concerning the Angela Davis Case.
